selected_quotes: Our scientific paper on editing the genome towards treating sickle cell anemia
Investigadores australianos editan el genoma para introducir cambios beneficiosos en la globina fetal
Editing the genome to introduce a beneficial naturally occurring mutation associated ... ReadCube Articles
Genome editing to increase globin expression using TALENs - don't forget that techniques other than #CRISPR exist

citation.abstract: Genetic disorders resulting from defects in the adult globin genes are among the most common inherited diseases. Symptoms worsen from birth as fetal γ-globin expression is silenced. Genome editing could permit the introduction of beneficial single-nucleotide variants to ameliorate symptoms. Here, as proof of concept, we introduce the naturally occurring Hereditary Persistance of Fetal Haemoglobin (HPFH) -175T>C point mutation associated with elevated fetal γ-globin into erythroid cell lines. We show that this mutation increases fetal globin expression through de novo recruitment of the activator TAL1 to promote chromatin looping of distal enhancers to the modified γ-globin promoter.
citation.title: Editing the genome to introduce a beneficial naturally occurring mutation associated with increased fetal globin

news.title: DNA editing could reduce sickle cell symptoms
news.summary: Researchers say that editing haemoglobin DNA could help lessen symptoms in blood disease patients.

news.title: Sickle Cell Anemia Cure Foreseeable After Scientists Use Gene-Editing To Revert Hemoglobin Back To Neonatal State
news.summary: A recent breakthrough in gene-editing may lay the groundwork for a possible cure for blood disorders like sickle cell anemia.

news.title: Edición del ADN sería la clave para curar la anemia falciforme
news.summary: Estudio sugiere que este procedimiento disminuiría los síntomas de los males hereditarios que afectan la hemoglobina

news.title: Could genome editing be the cure for sickle-cell anemia?
news.summary: Chuck Bednar for redOrbit.com - @BednarChuck By introducing a beneficial, naturally occurring genetic mutation into the DNA of human red blood cells, researchers at the University of New South Wales (UNSW) Australia have come up with a technique that could

news.title: Turning the tables: using genetic mutations to fix nature's problems
news.summary: Genetic therapy might be able to reverse the harmful effects of sickle cell anaemia. Keith Chambers , CC BY Everyone is different. That’s a simple truism, but it’s is also true when it comes to how people respond to diseases; some people are laid low and o

news.title: Scientists Change A Single Letter In DNA, Enhancing Production Of Hemoglobin By Activating A Dormant Gene
news.summary: Scientists have successfully altered human DNA to switch on a dormant gene and have cells producing more hemoglobin. Australian scientists managed to recode human DNA, thereby paving way, for radical new treatments that are unheard of before. Scientists fr

news.title: Africa: DNA Editing Could Reduce Sickle Cell Symptoms
news.summary: [SciDev.Net] Editing the DNA of human blood cells has the potential to significantly reduce the impact of hereditary blood diseases such as sickle cell anaemia and thalassaemia, according to researchers from Australia and the United States.

facebook.title: Editing the genome to introduce a beneficial naturally occurring mutation associated with...

facebook.summary:
Genome editing to to treat inherited diseases

Genetic disorders resulting from defects in the adult globin genes are among the most common inherited diseases. Symptoms worsen from birth as fetal γ-globin expression is silenced.

Adult expression of fetal

facebook.title: Editing the genome to introduce a beneficial naturally occurring mutation associated with...
facebook.summary: Investigadores australianos editan el genoma para introducir cambios beneficiosos en la globina fetal, lo que podría abrir el camino hacia el tratamiento de la anemia falciforme y otros desórdenes de la sangre

blogs.title: ‘Waking Up’ Fetal Hemoglobin To Treat Blood Disorders
blogs.summary: Researchers have demonstrated that gene editing can be used to re-introduce a fetal form of hemoglobin, thereby treating sickle cell anemia.
